awd_titl_txt: RUI: Undergraduate Research in Musical Acoustics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports two experimental investigations into the physics of musical instruments. The two projects represent complex problems involving energy transfer between vibrating structures and the air flow that produces the vibration. One goal is to determine if the vibration of the tubing of brass wind instruments in the direction of the air flow is the primary reason that the material and bracing of the instrument affects the sound. If this is found to be the case, it will answer a question that has been debated in the scientific literature for over a century. The second goal is to determine the physical parameters of a reed that are necessary to construct an accurate model of a clarinet during actual performance. The results of this study will enhance the ability to synthesize the sound of woodwind instruments and provide needed information concerning which parameters musical instrument designers should be adjusting to improve their instruments.

     The primary goal of the work is to involve undergraduate students, particularly women, in original scientific research. While the systems under study involve musical instruments, the research centers on studying basic physical phenomena that are not unique to musical acoustics. This work contributes to the understanding of some important physics, with both scientific and industrial applications, but more importantly it introduces undergraduate students to original scientific research through a subject they find fascinating.

por.por_cntn:
The research supported by this grant resulted in a more complete understanding of the complex interaction between airborne acoustical waves and the sources that produced them. Although the specific systems under study were musical instruments, the results have broad application to other scientific, engineering and industrial situations.

Investigations into the transient and steady-state motion of a clarinet reed during performance resulted in the development of a sensor-equipped mouthpiece that simultaneously measures differential pressure on the reed and reed displacement. This mouthpiece was used to study the interaction of the musician with the instrument during performance. The work resulted in the development of an analytical method to determine whether the reed came in contact with the tongue simply by analyzing the sound of the instrument during play. This work has application to the study of musical style and technique from historical recordings, as well as to the in situ analysis of reed valves in industrial equipment.

Studies of the interaction between the bell motion of a trumpet and the acoustic energy inside the instrument were also conducted. It was found that the difference in sound produced when the motion of the bell section of trumpet is damped is partially due to the interference of the acoustic radiation from the mechanical motion of the bell and the sound from the internal acoustic standing wave. Previous work has shown that the mechanical vibrations produced by the acoustic energy internal to the instrument was responsible for part of the change in the sound. This interaction results in a change in the input impedance presented to the lips. However, this work has shown that the feedback between the bell motion and the driving mechanism is not the only way that bell vibrations affect the radiated sound. Part of the effect results from the sound produced by the mechanical motion of the waveguide interfering with the sound from the air column. This work has application to any situation where an oscillating acoustic signal is confined by a flaring metal waveguide. The oscillations may originate with lips, as in the case of the trumpet, or by fan noise inside metal ducts as is found in many industrial situations. It may also have application to speaker horn design.

The major effort of the work was to determine the etiology of phantom partials in the sound of the modern piano. The term phantom partial refers to anomalous frequency components found when analyzing the spectrum of the sound produced by a piano. For decades these anomalous frequencies, which occur at sum and difference frequencies of the overtones produced by the string motion, were assumed to originate in the forced longitudinal motion of the string. However, the results of this work have conclusively shown that the majority of the sound power in phantom partials originates in the structural components of the piano, not the strings. Further research demonstrated that it is the wood-on-wood contact in the structure that contributes most significantly, and a model of the process based on the theory of a contact nonlinearity was developed. This work has direct commercial application to the synthesis of piano sounds. Beyond the applications to musical instruments, however, this work holds promise as a method for nondestructive failure analysis of wooden structures.

The work was undertaken primarily by undergraduate students. The grant supported nine individual undergraduate students, most of them over multiple years. More than half of these students were women.
